author: catwith1hat
content: Censorship is not breaking any network rules. If we could punish censorship, blockchain consensus would become trivial because we would have "proof of message delivery", which our networks don't have. It might break social rules. Sure, but I'd rather have us work on an a priori positive enforcement statement like "RocketPool will be made whole in case of a hack", instead of a negative one "If Coinbase censors by some unclear definition of the word, it will be slashed." Social consensus for the latter will be harder, and I'd argue that agreeing on the former could achieve the same thing: Less centralization.

content: Not always.  We can detect, probabilistically, reorgs attacks after the fact as humans but we don't have a way of encoding it in the protocol that isn't gameable/broken.  This is a pretty hard and fast rule (bright line), but not protocol implemented.

author: sky.cactus
content: While the exact threshold is fuzzy, we can say that there exists a point that is across *everyone's* individual thresholds.

author: sky.cactus
content: By not encoding that point in the protocol, it protects us from gamification.  If there is a defined line, then an attacker can walk right up to that line and be confident they won't get hurt.  By not having the exact line defined in advance, and instead having it be something like a 95th percentile line of all individual users/core developers, but having all of those users and developers keep their individual lines private, we can protect against gamification that we would be susceptible to if this was in-protocol.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, out-of-protocol is more resistant to sybil and eclipse attacks.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think we can identify who is following fork choice rule and who isn't through analytics of publicly recorded history.

author: sky.cactus
content: In particular, if block 5 is proposed in slot 5 and 80% of validators attest to it and 20% don't, then a new block 5 is proposed in slot 6 and the first 20% of validators that attest to it are the same 20% who didn't attest to the block in slot 5, then the set of potential attackers is narrowed down to that 20%.  If you see the same 20% behaving in the same way over and over again, then we can safely assert that they are not following the fork choice rule.

author: sky.cactus
content: The 80% that attested to slot 5 will *eventually* also attest to slot 6, but only because the current fork choice rule (including proposer boost) will result in them switching heads only after 20% attest to the new head while it *isn't* the proper fork choice.

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially, we can look at attestation history and determine who is repeatedly violating the fork choice rule.  People may occasionally violate the fork choice rule just because of latency and whatnot, but what we care about is a pattern of behavior (which is why we have to deal with this at the social layer, not the code layer).
